sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Food Scientists use chemistry, microbiology, engineering, and other sciences to analyze food content for nutritional value, discover new food sources, and research ways to make processed foods safe, healthy, and delicious.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  They develop new or improved ways of preserving, processing, packaging, storing, and delivering foods.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Food Scientists also test new products for flavor, texture, color, nutritional content, and adherence to government and industry standards.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  They check finished products for safety, quality, and nutritional value.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Food Scientists also search for substitutes for harmful or undesirable food additives, demonstrate new products for clients, develop new food items for production, based on consumer feedback and run taste tests of new products to see if consumers will like them.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Finally, Molecular Biologists study how genes in cells cause biological characteristics and functions in organisms.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  They study the detailed genetic make-up of plants, animals, humans, bacteria, and fungi.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  They also study DNA for medical testing for disease-causing organisms and to test for inherited genetic disorders.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Molecular Biologists also manipulate genes to breed new crop plants or livestock, aid in the development of new medicines, and use DNA fingerprinting to provide law enforcement with evidence to help solve crimes.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  	These are just some of the many careers available in microbiology.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic: There are many different type of microbes, such as bacteria, fungi, parasites, and viruses.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Viruses are the smallest microbes, which scientists study in the field of microbiology.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  A virus is not made up of cells, thus it is unable to carry out cellular functions.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  In order to reproduce a virus must invade a cell and use the cell’s organelles, which are small organ-like parts of the cell.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Viruses do not have organelles.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  The coat of the virus is called the capsid but other viruses have an outer structure called an envelope.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Capsid holds the viruses’ nucleic acid.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  The shape of virus is determined by the nucleic acid and capsid.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Definition of Viral Gastroenteritis Norovirus is the most common cause of Viral Gastroenteritis, the largest contributor of foodborne-disease outbreaks in the United States.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  You can get Norovirus from an infected person, contaminated food or water, or by touching contaminated surfaces.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Anyone can be infected with Norovirus and get sick.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Also, you can have Viral Gastroenteritis many times in your life.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  The virus causes your stomach or intestines or both to get inflamed.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Common symptoms include stomach pain, nausea, diarrhea, and vomiting.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  This can lead to dehydration, especially in young children, older adults, and people with other illnesses.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Most people with Viral Gastroenteritis get better within 1 to 3 days.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Prevention of Viral Gastroenteritis Wash your hands carefully with soap and water, especially after using the toilet and changing diapers.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  It is also important to wash your hands before eating, preparing, or handling food.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Noroviruses can be found in your vomit or stool even before you start feeling sick.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  The virus can stay in your stool for 2 weeks or more after you feel better, so it is important to continue washing your hands often during this time.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  There is no specific therapy to treat people with Viral Gastroenteritis caused by Norovirus infection.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Dehydration is the most common complication that may require medical care.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Treatment includes replacing fluids lost from vomiting and diarrhea and correcting electrolyte disturbances.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Oral rehydration fluids and giving fluids intravenously are used for severe dehydration.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Imagine hearing the following at the doctor's office.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  “I don’t know what is wrong, Doctor.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  I am covered in small red spots all over my body.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Most of the spots are on my face, hands, and feet.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic: ” When the doctor hears this, he may diagnose the patient with smallpox.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  This would be a very unusual diagnosis, because smallpox has been virtually wiped out by an effective worldwide vaccination program.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Today, the smallpox virus is only found in research settings.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Smallpox is caused by the Variola virus, which is passed from person to person by extended direct contact.
labels: virus

sentence: Type: CI, topic: What is a Mutagen?
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  The genetic change in an organism caused by a physical or chemical agent is called a mutation.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  The physical or chemical agent is called a mutagen.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Not all mutations are caused by mutagens.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  A naturally occurring mutation may occur because of an error in DNA replication.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  This is called spontaneous mutation.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Mutagens may cause cancer.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  An agent that causes cancer is called a carcinogen.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  A carcinogen may be mutagen, and a mutagen may be a carcinogen.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  History of Mutagens Hippocrates first studied physical changes in living things around 500 B.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic: C.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  He observed tumors and called them karkinos, which is the word that cancer is derived from.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Genetic changes were first linked to mutagens in 1927.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Hermann Muller discovered that electromagnetic radiation, commonly called x-rays, could cause genetic mutations in fruit flies.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  The next generation of fruit flies had a clear change in the chromosomes from the parental chromosomes.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  It was later shown that the use of x-rays also could change the genetic makeup of humans too.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  It was not until the 1940s that chemicals, like x-rays, were shown to cause mutations in living cells.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  These first studies were also done on fruit flies.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Types of Mutagens Mutagens may be found as physical, chemical, or biological agents.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  An example of a physical mutagen is radiation, such as x-rays or gamma radiation.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Chemicals, such as benzene or arsenic, may also create changes to DNA, as well as processes associated with DNA replication.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  DNA is the basic genetic code of a cell.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Biological agents, which can act as mutagens, include viruses and bacteria.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  For example, a virus can insert its DNA into a cell and cause problems for the cell.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Some bacteria may also cause mutations by interfering with cellular processes.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  There are several steps that may be taken in order to decrease the chances of being affected by mutagens.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  You may choose to eat more fruits and vegetables, which contain antioxidants.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  You may also choose to limit your exposure to physical mutagens such as ultraviolet radiation and tobacco smoke or polluted air.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  There are also positive uses for mutagens.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic: The human body has many systems, each of which has a specific function.
labels: prevention

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  For example, the immune system has the job of keeping the body healthy.
labels: prevention

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  This system is able to recognize when the body is infiltrated with outside organisms, such as bacteria, parasites, virus, or fungi.
labels: prevention

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  The immune system is composed of several organs including the lymph nodes.
labels: prevention

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  The lymph nodes are found throughout the body.
labels: prevention

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  One important function for the nodes is to filter fluids circulating in the body.
labels: prevention

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  These nodes also store the materials that can fight infections.
labels: prevention

sentence: Type: CI, topic: What is Microbiology?
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Microbiology is a category of science that studies one-celled organisms.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  We cannot see the cell with the human eye although cells can be viewed through microscopes.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  To help you understand the small size of an individual cell, consider that the human body is made up of about 75 trillion cells.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Cells are the smallest structural units of an organism capable of functioning independently.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  In the year 1665, Robert Hooke was one of the first scientists to view cells under his light microscope.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Hooke viewed the cells of a plant and recognized these as clusters of cellulae.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Cellulae is the Latin word for tiny storage rooms.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  About 175 years later, botanists (plant biologists) and zoologists (animal biologists) used light microscopes to see differences between plant and animal cells.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Scientists continued to study and observe with strong microscopes then they discovered molecules of acid and molecules of fat.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Types of Cells There are several types of cell categories.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  When learning about cell biology, it is helpful to think about all the information plugged into categories.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Sorting by how things are alike or different is an important part of the job of the microbiologist.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Cell categories are all of the following: animal, plant, bacteria, fungi, and virus structures.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  We can describe cells by characteristics or attributes.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  The animal cell is enclosed by a membrane-bound nucleus.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Within the membrane there is a nucleus that contains genetic material.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Animal cells have small whip-like structures that can help with locomotion.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  The plant cell is more rigid, with a wall enclosing it.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Bacteria are a type of prokaryotic cell without a nucleus.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  The virus has a simple structure of genetic material surrounded by a protein coat.
labels: microbe

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Bacteria are tiny living organisms that are found everywhere.
labels: bacteria

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  You have to use a microscope to see them.
labels: bacteria

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  They are found everywhere in the world and even inside other living things.
labels: bacteria

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Bacteria come in several different shapes and that is how many of them are identified.
labels: bacteria

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Bacteria called cocci are shaped like little round balls.
labels: bacteria

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Some of these bacteria live all by themselves, but some cocci group together like beads on a string (streptococci) or in clumps like grapes (staphylococci).
labels: bacteria

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Other bacteria are rod-shaped, like little hot dogs.
labels: bacteria

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  They are called bacilli.
labels: bacteria

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Still others are like little spirals, and are called spirilli.
labels: bacteria

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Some even have tails and can swim through liquids! The names of some bacteria can give you a clue about their shape.
labels: bacteria

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Many people think that bacteria are all bad, but there are many bacteria that are actually good for you.
labels: bacteria

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  In fact, you couldn’t be healthy without some types of bacteria.
labels: bacteria

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Bacteria on your skin help keep the number of good and bad bacteria in balance so you don’t get rashes and pimples.
labels: bacteria

sentence: Type: CI, topic:  Bacteria inside your intestines help you digest food and fight off other harmful bacteria.
labels: bacteria

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim first# (opening)
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim first# Welcome back, Agent! People on the island are getting sick again, and we need your help to diagnose the outbreak. Please, can you help us?
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim first# How can I help?
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim first# You can gather clues by talking to other team members, exploring the camp, and running tests in the laboratory.  To solve the mystery, you must complete the diagnosis worksheet, then come talk to me once you’re finished.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim first# What do you know so far?
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim first# The illness first appeared several weeks ago, and it has spread among our team of scientists on the island. We are not sure how it is spreading. All we know is that it is either a pathogen, a mutagen, or a carcinogen.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim first# What is a pathogen?
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim first# Pathogens are biological organisms that cause disease or illness to their host.  The main characteristics of pathogens are that they make people ill, they require hosts, and can spread from one host to another.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim first# What is a mutagen?
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim first# Mutagens are agents that can change the genetic information, like DNA, of organisms.  Some mutagens cause cancer, making them carcinogens as well.  Mutagens cannot spread from person to person like pathogens.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim first# What is a carcinogen?
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim first# Carcinogens are agents that promote or facilitate cancer.  Cancers are diseases that affect the cells of patients' bodies.  Carcinogens cannot spread from one person to the next like pathogens.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim first# I should go.
labels: cause

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# (opening)
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# Hello again, Agent! We really need your help.
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# How can I help?
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# You can gather clues by talking to other team members, exploring the camp, and running tests in the laboratory.  To solve the mystery, you must complete the diagnosis worksheet, then come talk to me once you’re finished.
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# What do you know so far?
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# The illness first appeared several weeks ago, and it has spread among our team of scientists on the island. We are not sure how it is spreading. All we know is that it is either a pathogen, a mutagen, or a carcinogen.
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# I have a diagnosis.
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# Let's look at your diagnosis worksheet to check your progress.
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# worksheet error disease
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# Hmm, I'm not sure this is quite right. You should take another look at your diagnosis. Make sure the disease’s characteristics match the sick team members’ symptoms and lab results.
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# worksheet error transmission source
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# Hmm, I'm not sure this is quite right. You should take another look at your transmission source. The transmission source should test positive for an infectious agent in the laboratory.
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# worksheet error treatment
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# Hmm, I'm not sure this is quite right. You should take another look at your treatment and prevention plan. Remember, the plan depends on the type of infection that the team members have.
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# worksheet correct
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# This diagnosis makes perfect sense!  We'll start a treatment plan right away. Thanks for your help, Agent!
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# Transition to Congratulations / Game Over Screen
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim standard# I should go.
labels: method

sentence: Type: CI, topic: Kim hint# What should I do next?
labels: method

sentence: Type: GameHelp_Collaboration, response: How can I make a claim that sounds convincing?
labels: A convincing argument is one that is supported by a lot of evidence from trustworthy sources. Make sure you've gathered information from different people and places, and that all of the information makes sense and supports your argument together.

sentence: Type: GameHelp_Collaboration, response: what is good teamwork?

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is pollination?
labels: Pollination is how plants reproduce, which happens when pollen is moved from the male part of the flower to the female part.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do flowers get pollinated?
labels: Flowers can be pollinated by wind, by animals and insects, and by people. A flower is pollinated when pollen is moved from the male part of the flower to the female part of the flower.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What are the parts of a flower?
labels: The parts of a flower include the petals, the stamen, and the pistil. The stamen is made up of the anther and filament, while the pistil is made up of the stigma, style, and ovary. Try exploring the diagrams in the lab to see what they look like.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is the stamen?
labels: The stamen is the male part of the flower that produces pollen. It has a thin stick-like filament and an anther on top where bees and other insects can pick up pollen.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is the pistil?
labels: The pistil is the female part of the flower that produces fruits and seeds after it is pollinated. It has a stigma where pollen is collected, and then the pollen travels into the ovary at the base of the flower where the fruit and seeds are grown.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do bees help with pollination?
labels: Bees help with pollination by transferring pollen from one flower to another while collecting nectar.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is nectar?
labels: Nectar is a sweet liquid produced by flowers to attract pollinators.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What do bees do in pollination? How do bees pollinate flowers?
labels: Bees pollinate flowers by transfering pollen from one flower to another while collecting nectar, which they bring back to the hive and turn into honey.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do bees find flowers to pollinate?
labels: Bees find flowers to pollinate using their sense of sight, smell, and memory. They also communicate with each other to tell other bees where the good flowers are.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What are the different types of bees that help with pollination?
labels: The different types of bees that help with pollination include honeybees, bumblebees, and solitary bees.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do bees collect nectar?
labels: Bees collect nectar by sucking it out of the flower using their proboscis, which is a tongue that acts kind of like a straw.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: Why do bees need nectar?
labels: Bees need nectar to make honey and feed their young.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is the difference between pollination and fertilization?
labels: Pollination is the transfer of pollen from the male reproductive organ to the female reproductive organ, while fertilization is the fusion of a sperm and an egg to form a seed.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How does pollination help plants?
labels: Pollination helps plants reproduce and produce seeds.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do plants attract pollinators?
labels: Plants attract pollinators using their bright colors, sweet scent, and nectar.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: Why are bees important to our environment?
labels: Bees are important to our environment because they help pollinate plants, which in turn produce food for us and other animals.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What happens if bees disappear?
labels: If bees disappeared, it would have a devastating impact on our food supply and the environment.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is the lifecycle of a bee?
labels: The lifecycle of a bee includes the egg, larva, pupa, and adult stages.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How long do bees live?
labels: Some bees, like worker bees and drones, only live for 2-6 weeks, while others, like the queen bee, can live for several years.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do bees communicate with each other?
labels: Bees communicate with each other using pheromones and dances.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is the difference between honeybees and bumblebees?
labels: Honeybees and bumblebees have different body shapes and nesting habits.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is a queen bee?
labels: A queen bee is the only reproductive female in a colony of bees.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do bees make honey?
labels: Bees make honey by collecting nectar from flowers and storing it in their hives. The honey sacs in their stomachs help convert the nectar into honey, and the liquid also evaporates while the honey is being stored in the hive.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is the difference between a drone bee and a worker bee?
labels: A drone bee is a male bee that mates with the queen, while a worker bee is a female bee that performs various tasks in the hive.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How many flowers can a bee pollinate in a day?
labels: A bee can pollinate hundreds of flowers in a day.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What are some other pollinators besides bees?
labels: Other pollinators besides bees include butterflies, birds, and bats.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do butterflies help with pollination?
labels: Butterflies help with pollination by drinking nectar and transferring pollen on their bodies.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do birds help with pollination?
labels: Birds help with pollination by eating nectar and fruit, and transferring pollen on their feathers.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How does wind pollinate plants?
labels: Wind helps with pollination by carrying pollen from one flower to another. Many types of trees are pollinated by the wind.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How does climate change affect pollinators?
labels: Climate change affects pollinators by altering their habitat and food sources.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How can we help protect pollinators?
labels: We can help protect pollinators by planting pollinator-friendly flowers and avoiding the use of pesticides.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do bees make their hives?
labels: Bees make their hives by collecting plant resins and mixing it with wax that they can produce in their bodies. They chew on this wax and shape it into hexagons to build their honeycomb.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is the importance of biodiversity?
labels: Biodiversity is important for maintaining healthy ecosystems and supporting a variety of species. Having lots of different plants, animals, and microorganisms helps our planet to be healthy and keeps ecosystems balanced.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is biodiversity?
labels: Biodiversity means all the different living things in an area, including, plants, animals, and microorganisms.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What are some challenges faced by pollinators?
labels: Some challenges faced by pollinators include habitat loss, pesticide use, and climate change.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is the difference between a monoculture and a diverse ecosystem?
labels: A monoculture is a single crop grown in a large area, while a diverse ecosystem has many different species of plants.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is a pesticide?
labels: Pesticides are chemicals used to kill pests, but they can also harm non-target organisms like bees.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do pesticides affect bees?
labels: A pesticide can harm bees by killing them directly or by impairing their ability to navigate and forage.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is an ecosystem?
labels: An ecosystem is a community of living organisms and nonliving parts of their environment such as air, water, soil, and sunlight. All the parts of the ecosystem interact together and impact each other.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What does a queen bee do?
labels: The queen bee lays eggs, which hatch into larvae that are fed by worker bees until they pupate and emerge as adult bees.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do bees work together?
labels: Bees work together in a colony to perform tasks like foraging, caring for young, and defending the hive.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do bees show each other where food is?
labels: Bees use their waggle dance to communicate the location of food sources to other bees in the colony.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is a waggle dance?
labels: The waggle dance involves a bee waggling its body and moving in a figure-eight pattern.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How far do bees fly?
labels: Bees can travel several miles from their hive to find food sources.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: Why are bees important for farming?
labels: Bees are important for pollinating crops like almonds, apples, and blueberries. Without bees, many crops would have to be pollinated by hand, which would be time-consuming and expensive.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How fast can bees fly?
labels: Bees can fly up to 15 miles per hour.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do bees store nectar?
labels: Bees have a special organ called a honey stomach or honey sac, which they use to store nectar until they return to the hive.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do bees affect the environment? How do bees contribute to the ecosystem?
labels: Bees play an important role in maintaining the biodiversity of ecosystems by helping to pollinate a variety of plant species.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do bees benefit from flowers?
labels: Flowers provide bees with food for the hive.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is the difference between a flower and a fruit?
labels: A flower produces and collects pollen, and it can eventually grow a fruit if it is pollinated.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is the difference between a seed and a spore?
labels: Flowering plants produce seeds. Spores are produced by algae, fungi, bacteria, and non-flowering plants. Seeds can dry up and be moved to other places, and they are protected from the elements by a shell. Spores need water to survive and have to grow where they land.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is the purpose of a plant’s roots?
labels: Roots gather water and nutrients for the plant.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is the function of a plant’s leaves?
labels: A plant's leaves use sunlight to convert water and carbon dioxide into sugars that the plant can use as energy.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do plants absorb water?
labels: Plants absorb water through the process of osmosis, which pulls water up through their roots from the soil.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What is photosynthesis?
labels: Photosynthesis is the process where plants absorb sunlight through their leaves and uses this energy, in combination with water and carbon dioxide, to create food for the plant.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What are some examples of flowering plants?
labels: Tomatoes, zucchinis, and watermelons are all examples of flowering plants. Almost any fruit you can think of came from a flowering plant!

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do bees help with food production?
labels: Bees help us grow food by pollinating flowers, which is essential to grow many of the food crops that we eat!

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How can we encourage more pollinators to visit our gardens?
labels: We can encourage pollinators to visit our gardens by planting a variety of native plants that are good food sources for them. Pollinators are often attracted by bright flowers and high quality nectar.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How is honey harvested?
labels: Beekeepers harvest honey by removing an extra panel from the hive and gently encouraing the bees to move away from it by using a fume board, which has a smell bees don't like.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How can we support local beekeepers?
labels: You can support local beekeepers in your community by buying local honey from the farmer's market, as well as other products they sell made from beeswax.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What are some crops that rely heavily on pollinators?
labels: Lots of crops rely on honeybees, including melons, apples, broccoli, almonds, cranberries, pumpkins, and other squash.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How does weather impact bees?
labels: Bad weather can make it harder for bees to fly and find food. If it's raining hard, bees will stay inside the hive. The more nice weather we have, the more time in the day bees can fly around searching for flowers with good nectar.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What happens if the beehive gets full of honey?
labels: In nature, if the hive gets full of food, some of the bees might split off and build a new hive. For bees in human-made hives, beekeepers can just take the extra honey out to leave room for new nectar to be collected.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: Do beekeepers take away bees food?
labels: Beekeepers only harvest extra honey that the bees don't need, so they leave plenty of honey in the hive for the bees to use over the winter.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: Do bees need a variety of different flowers?
labels: Bees need access to lots of different flowers, because different types of flowers have different types of nectar and pollen. Some are more nutritious than others, and some have less food that bees can eat.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: Why do bees eat both nectar and pollen?
labels: Nectar gives bees carbohydrates, and pollen gives them protein. They need a balanced diet with all the right nutrients, just like humans do!

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What do bees need to be healthy?
labels: Healthy bees have a variety of nectar and pollen sources so that they can get all of the food that they need. Nectar gives bees carbohydrates, and pollen gives them protein. They need a balanced diet with all the right nutrients, just like humans do!

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: Do bees get hot?
labels: Yes, bees get hot just like people! On a hot and humid day, the bees sometimes "beard" (sit in big groups) on the outside of the hive to help let air flow into the hive and cool it down.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: Does pollination change how fruits grow?
labels: Pollination can make fruits and veggies grow bigger, more brightly colored, and more nicely shaped. Even better, a well-pollinated fruit will taste better and won't spoil as quickly!

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How does pollination impact the food we grow?
labels: Pollination can make fruits and veggies grow bigger, more brightly colored, and more nicely shaped. Even better, a well-pollinated fruit will taste better and won't spoil as quickly!

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How does pollination help us grow better food?
labels: Pollination can make fruits and veggies grow bigger, more brightly colored, and more nicely shaped. Even better, a well-pollinated fruit will taste better and won't spoil as quickly!

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: Does pollination make fruits better?
labels: Pollination can make fruits and veggies grow bigger, more brightly colored, and more nicely shaped. Even better, a well-pollinated fruit will taste better and won't spoil as quickly!

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: Do all flowers have pollen?
labels: No, not all plants produce pollen. Sometimes they have spores or reproduce in ways that don't require pollen. But it's very common for flowering plants to have pollen.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do bees know if a flower has pollen?
labels: Bees look for nectar using lots of senses, including a highly developed sense of smell, sight, touch, and taste. They can also remember if a flower has good nectar or pollen.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What's the difference between nectar and pollen?
labels: Nectar is a sweet liquid produced by flowers to attract pollinators, and pollen is a sort of powder like substance that helps plants to reproduce.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: Why do bees pollinate?
labels: Bees accidentely pick up pollen and move it from one flower to another when they are collecting nectar. They need nectar to make honey.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: Are bees the only ways flowers get polllinated?
labels: Bees are common pollinators, but flowers can also be pollinated in other ways, like by butterflies, moths, birds, and bats!

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: I thought flowers already have pollen why do they need more?
labels: You're right, most flowers do produce their own pollen, but they need some from other flowers to fertilize their seeds and to reproduce.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do flowers become fruits?
labels: Flowers become fruits in a process called fertilization. Parts of the flower develop into seeds, and a fruit develops around the seeds. Pollination makes fruits bigger, brioghter, and better tasting!

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: Can people help with pollination?
labels: Yes, humans can help by planting flowers that attract bees.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How long does pollination take?
labels: Pollination happen in a couple of seconds as bees move from flower to flower.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How many kinds of bees are there?
labels: There are more than 20,000 kinds of bees all around the world!

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How do bees talk to each other?
labels: Bees use a waggle dance to communicate the location of food sources to other bees in the colony.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: Do bees use pollen to make honey?
labels: Bees collect nectar from flowers and turn it into honey in their hives.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What happens to flowers with no bees?
labels: Without bees, many plants would not be able to make seeds and fruits or reproduce.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: Do bees pollinate in the winter?
labels: Bees can pollinate throughout the year, but mostly during the warmer months in spring and summer, when flowers are in bloom and there's lots of nectar!

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: When do bees pollinate?
labels: Bees can pollinate throughout the year, but mostly during the warmer months in spring and summer, when flowers are in bloom and there's lots of nectar!

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: What do you think of the parking lot idea?
labels: I'm not a big fan of the parking lot idea. Gardens are better for the community because they provide food for bees and for people, too!

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: Does having more parking lots impact pollination?
labels: Bees aren't going to bother flying to an area that doesn't have many flowers. So if people are trying to grow fruits and veggies in areas without much green space, it will be harder to attract pollinators.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_Pollination, response: How is pollination related to parking lots vs. gardens?
labels: Bees aren't going to bother flying to an area that doesn't have many flowers. So if people are trying to grow fruits and veggies in areas without much green space, it will be harder to attract pollinators.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: Why is access to healthy food important?
labels: Access to healthy food is important because it helps us grow, stay healthy, and have the energy we need to do the things we love. Healthy food can also prevent diseases like obesity, heart disease, and diabetes.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: Why should we plant community gardens?
labels: Community gardens provide fresh produce in areas with limited access to healthy food, empowering communities to take control of their food and learn sustainable agriculture practices. Community gardens can also bring people together and help them learn new skills.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How do corporations influence food systems?
labels: Corporations have a big role in the food system because they control a lot of the production and distribution of food. Sometimes, they prioritize profit over providing healthy and affordable food for everyone, which can contribute to food injustice.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: What is fair trade? How does fair trade relate to food justice?
labels: Fair trade is a certification that ensures farmers and workers are paid fairly for their labor and products. It relates to food justice because it supports the rights and livelihoods of those who grow and produce our food.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: Why can't people just eat fast food?
labels: Fast food is often high in fat, salt, and sugar, and low in nutrients like vitamins and minerals. Fast food companies often target low-income communities with advertising and offer cheap, convenient options that can harm our bodies if we don't also have access to nutritious food options.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: What is food apartheid?
labels: Food apartheid is the systematic discrimination and segregation of people of color from healthy and affordable food options. This can happen through the lack of grocery stores and farmers' markets in low-income neighborhoods, where fast food may be the only affordable option.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: What are food banks?
labels: Food banks are organizations that collect and distribute donated food to people in need. They help combat food insecurity by providing emergency food assistance to individuals and families who may not have access to enough food.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: What are food co-ops? How do food co-ops promote food justice?
labels: Food co-ops are community-owned grocery stores that prioritize local, organic, and sustainable foods. They promote food justice by providing access to healthy food and supporting local farmers.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: What are food deserts?
labels: Food deserts are areas where it's hard to find healthy food, like fresh fruits and vegetables. This is often because there are no grocery stores or farmers markets nearby.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How do food deserts impact communities?
labels: Food deserts can impact communities by making it harder for people to eat healthy, leading to health problems.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How do food deserts impact rural communities?
labels: Food deserts can impact rural communities by limiting access to healthy food options, which can lead to more people in these areas experiencing health problems. This can be especially challenging in rural areas where there may be fewer grocery stores and farmers' markets.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: What is the impact of food deserts on health?
labels: Food deserts can lead to limited access to healthy foods, which can impact health by contributing to obesity, malnutrition, and other health issues.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How does food insecurity affect mental health?
labels: Food insecurity can cause stress, anxiety, and depression, which can affect mental health. People who are food insecure may also have a harder time concentrating in school or work.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How does food insecurity impact students?
labels: Food insecurity can impact student performance in school by making it harder for students to focus and learn. When students don't have enough to eat, they may have lower energy levels and struggle to concentrate.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: What is the impact of food insecurity on physical health?
labels: Food insecurity can lead to malnutrition, which can cause problems like stunted growth, weakened immune systems, and increased risk of chronic diseases like diabetes and heart disease. In children, food insecurity can also lead to developmental delays and problems with learning.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How does food insecurity impact the elderly?
labels: Many older adults live on fixed incomes or have health problems that limit their ability to shop for and prepare food. For them, food insecurity can lead to malnutrition and physical health problems, as well as social isolation and mental health problems like depression.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: What is food justice activism?
labels: Food justice activism is the work of advocating for equal access to healthy, sustainable, and culturally appropriate food for all people.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How does food justice relate to climate change?
labels: Food justice and climate justice are connected! Industrial agriculture, food transportation, and food waste all generate greenhouse gas emissions that harm the environment. Food justice advocates encourage sustainable agriculture to help reduce our carbon footprint.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How does food justice relate to social justice?
labels: Food justice is an important part of social justice because access to healthy and nutritious food is a basic human right. The lack of access to healthy food options affects low-income communities and communities of color the most, which makes existing social inequalities worse.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: What is food justice?
labels: Food justice is the idea that everyone should have access to healthy, affordable, and culturally appropriate food, regardless of where they live, how much money they have, or their race or ethnicity.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How do food labels impact food justice?
labels: Food labels can impact food justice by providing consumers with information about the nutritional content and sourcing of their food. Clear and accurate labeling can help consumers make informed decisions about their food choices and hold companies accountable for their practices.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How does food waste impact communities?
labels: Food waste can impact communities because food that is wasted could have been used to feed people who don't have enough to eat.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How does food waste contribute to climate change?
labels: Food waste contributes to climate change by releasing methane gas as it decomposes in landfills. Methane is a potent greenhouse gas that is a major contributor to global warming.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How does food waste impact the environment?
labels: Food waste has a big impact on the environment because it contributes to greenhouse gas emissions and uses up resources like water and energy.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: What is gentrification? How does gentrification impact food deserts?
labels: Gentrification is when wealthy people move into a neighborhood and the cost of living goes up, making it harder for low-income residents to afford things like healthy food. This can lead to food deserts and limited options for healthy eating.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How does the food system impact biodiversity?
labels: Industrial agriculture practices like pesticide use and only planting a few types of crops can lead to a loss of biodiversity and can harm our natural ecosystems. Sustainable agriculture practices like community gardens can help protect biodiversity and promote environmental sustainability.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How can schools be involved in food justice?
labels: One way to bring food justice to your school is to advocate for policies that prioritize fresh, whole foods and limit the amount of processed and sugary foods served in schools. Parents and students can get involved in school food councils and advocate for changes in their school's food program.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How can we ensure that everyone has access to culturally appropriate food?
labels: Community gardens and urban agriculture can provide a diversity of fresh produce that reflects the cultural diversity of the community, so that everyone has access to culturally appropriate food.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How can we make sure everyone has access to healthy food?
labels: One way to help everyone get access to affordable and healthy food options is by supporting local farmers markets and community gardens. It's also important to advocate for policies that promote healthy food options.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: Can the government help with food deserts?
labels: The government can play a role in promoting food justice by creating policies and programs that support healthy and sustainable food systems, such as funding for local agriculture, school meal programs, and regulations that promote fair labor practices.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How does our current food system impact food justice?
labels: The industrial food system is designed to produce large quantities of food at a low cost, often at the expense of workers, the environment, and public health. This can limit access to healthy food and perpetuate inequality.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How can we help people in food deserts get food?
labels: There are many ways to increase access to fresh produce in food deserts, like building community gardens, supporting farmers markets, and creating mobile markets that bring fresh produce directly to neighborhoods.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: What is urban agriculture? How does urban agriculture promote food justice?
labels: Urban agriculture is the practice of growing food in cities, often in community gardens or on rooftops. It promotes food justice by increasing access to fresh produce and creating local jobs.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How can we help communities improve their food systems?
labels: We can help communities by fighting for food democracy, which means that everyone has a say in what kind of food they want to eat and how it is produced. Communities can create sustainable and locally-based food systems that meet their needs.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How can we help people learn about food?
labels: We can help people learn about food by teaching knowledge and skills needed to make healthy and informed food choices. This also gives people the tools to advocate for changes in the food system that promote health and sustainability.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How can we make sure that farmers are paid fairly for their work?
labels: We can make sure that farmers are paid fairly for their work by supporting fair trade practices, buying locally grown food, and advocating for policies that protect worker rights.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How can we promote food justice in our own communities?
labels: We can promote food justice in our own communities by supporting local farmers and businesses that provide healthy and affordable food and educating ourselves and others about the importance of sustainable food systems.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How can we reduce food waste?
labels: We can reduce food waste by buying only what we need, storing food properly, and finding creative ways to use up leftovers. We can also support policies that encourage businesses to donate food that would otherwise go to waste.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How can we support small farmers and local food systems?
labels: We can support small farmers and local food systems by purchasing food from farmers' markets, joining community-supported agriculture programs, and advocating for policies that support small-scale and sustainable agriculture.

sentence: Type: Knowledge_FoodJustice, response: How can I help support food justice?
labels: You can help support food justice by volunteering at local food banks or community gardens, supporting local farmers and food co-ops, and advocating for policies that promote food justice.

sentence: Type: GEMSTEP_Modeling, response: What is a model?
labels: A model is a way to explore and represent how things work in the real world. Models aren't exactly like the real thing, but they can help us test out and play with things that are hard to see otherwise.

sentence: Type: GEMSTEP_Modeling, response: What does the bee eat?
labels: Bees eat honey and bee bread, which is a mixture of nectar and pollen. Bee bread provides protein, while honey is a source of carbohydrates. Both pollen and honey contain minerals, vitamins, and enzymes.
